quote: If you shall chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on
foot, you shall see, as I have said, great
difference betwixt our Bohemia and your Sicilia.
I think, this coming summer, the King of Sicilia
means to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.

As potent as a lord's. Will you go yet?
Force me to keep you as a prisoner,
My prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily,'

Of my lord's tricks and yours when you were boys:
You were pretty lordings then?
We were, fair queen,
Two lads that thought there was no more behind
And to be boy eternal.
Was not my lord

O my most sacred lady!
In those unfledged days was my wife a girl;
Your queen and I are devils: yet go on;
He'll stay my lord.
Hermione, my dearest, thou never spokest
To better purpose.
Never?
Never, but once.
I prithee tell me; cram's with praise, and make's

Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death,

To mingle friendship far is mingling bloods.
I have tremor cordis on me: my heart dances;
From heartiness, from bounty, fertile bosom,

Ay, my good lord.

Yes, if you will, my lord.

How, my lord!
What cheer? how is't with you, best brother?
Are you moved, my lord?
How sometimes nature will betray its folly,
Its tenderness, and make itself a pastime
To harder bosoms! Looking on the lines
Of my boy's face, methoughts I did recoil
How like, methought, I then was to this kernel,
This squash, this gentleman. Mine honest friend,
Will you take eggs for money?
No, my lord, I'll fight.
You will! why, happy man be's dole! My brother,
Are you so fond of your young prince as we
Now my sworn friend and then mine enemy,
My parasite, my soldier, statesman, all:
Thoughts that would thick my blood.
Officed with me: we two will walk, my lord,
And leave you to your graver steps. Hermione,
How thou lovest us, show in our brother's welcome;
Apparent to my heart.
Though you perceive me not how I give line.
How she holds up the neb, the bill to him!
And arms her with the boldness of a wife
Gone already!
Go, play, boy, play: thy mother plays, and I
Will be my knell. Go, play, boy, play.
Or I am much deceived, cuckolds ere now;
And many a man there is, even at this present,
Now while I speak this, holds his wife by the arm,
As mine, against their will. Should all despair
That have revolted wives, the tenth of mankind
Would hang themselves. Physic for't there is none;
With bag and baggage: many thousand on's
Have the disease, and feel't not. How now, boy!
Why that's some comfort. What, Camillo there?
Ay, my good lord.
Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man.
Camillo, this great sir will yet stay longer.
You had much ado to make his anchor hold:
His business more material.
'Sicilia is a so-forth:' 'tis far gone,

At the good queen's entreaty.

That seest a game play'd home, the rich stake drawn,
And takest it all for jest.
My gracious lord,
I may be negligent, foolish and fearful;
In every one of these no man is free,
But that his negligence, his folly, fear,
Sometime puts forth. In your affairs, my lord,
Not weighing well the end; if ever fearful
Against the non-performance, 'twas a fear
Which oft infects the wisest: these, my lord,
Is never free of. But, beseech your grace,
'Tis none of mine.
Ha' not you seen, Camillo,--
Is thicker than a cuckold's horn,--or heard,--
Cannot be mute,--or thought,--for cogitation
Resides not in that man that does not think,--
My wife is slippery? If thou wilt confess,
To have nor eyes nor ears nor thought, then say
My wife's a hobby-horse, deserves a name
I would not be a stander-by to hear
My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart,
You never spoke what did become you less
As deep as that, though true.
Is whispering nothing?
Of breaking honesty--horsing foot on foot?
Skulking in corners? wishing clocks more swift?
That would unseen be wicked? is this nothing?
Why, then the world and all that's in't is nothing;
The covering sky is nothing; Bohemia nothing;
My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings,
If this be nothing.
Good my lord, be cured
Of this diseased opinion, and betimes;
Say it be, 'tis true.
No, no, my lord.
I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee,
Inclining to them both: were my wife's liver
Infected as her life, she would not live
About his neck, Bohemia: who, if I
Had servants true about me, that bare eyes
To see alike mine honour as their profits,
His cupbearer,--whom I from meaner form
To give mine enemy a lasting wink;
Sir, my lord,
Maliciously like poison: but I cannot
So sovereignly being honourable.
I have loved thee,--
Give scandal to the blood o' the prince my son,
Who I do think is mine and love as mine,
Could man so blench?
I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't;
Will take again your queen as yours at first,
Even for your son's sake; and thereby for sealing
The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms
Even so as I mine own course have set down:
I'll give no blemish to her honour, none.
My lord,
As friendship wears at feasts, keep with Bohemia
And with your queen. I am his cupbearer:
Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart;
I'll do't, my lord.
O miserable lady! But, for me,
What case stand I in? I must be the poisoner
Of thousands that had struck anointed kings
Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one,
Here comes Bohemia.
My favour here begins to warp. Not speak?
Good day, Camillo.
None rare, my lord.
The king hath on him such a countenance
Loved as he loves himself: even now I met him
So leaves me to consider what is breeding
That changeth thus his manners.
I dare not know, my lord.

I have look'd on thousands, who have sped the better

I must be answer'd. Dost thou hear, Camillo,
I conjure thee, by all the parts of man

Is not this suit of mine, that thou declare
If not, how best to bear it.
Sir, I will tell you;
Since I am charged in honour and by him

On, good Camillo.
By whom, Camillo?
By the king.

By his great authority;

Dear gentlewoman,

As well as one so great and so forlorn

She is something before her time deliver'd.
A boy?
A daughter, and a goodly babe,

These dangerous unsafe lunes i' the king,

And never to my red-look'd anger be

Commend my best obedience to the queen:
I'll show't the king and undertake to be
Persuades when speaking fails.
Your honour and your goodness is so evident
That your free undertaking cannot miss
A thriving issue: there is no lady living
So meet for this great errand. Please your ladyship
To visit the next room, I'll presently
Acquaint the queen of your most noble offer;
But durst not tempt a minister of honour,
Tell her, Emilia.
As boldness from my bosom, let 't not be doubted
I'll to the queen: please you,

You need not fear it, sir:
This child was prisoner to the womb and is

If any be, the trespass of the queen.
Do not you fear: upon mine honour,

My lord?
How does the boy?
Conceiving the dishonour of his mother,
And downright languish'd. Leave me solely: go,
Fie, fie! no thought of him:
The thought of my revenges that way
Until a time may serve: for present vengeance,
Take it on her. Camillo and Polixenes
Laugh at me, make their pastime at my sorrow:
Nay, rather, good my lords, be second to me:
Fear you his tyrannous passion more, alas,
Than the queen's life? a gracious innocent soul,
Madam, he hath not slept tonight; commanded
None should come at him.
I come to bring him sleep. 'Tis such as you,
Nourish the cause of his awaking: I
Do come with words as medicinal as true,
No noise, my lord; but needful conference
Away with that audacious lady! Antigonus,
I told her so, my lord,
On your displeasure's peril and on mine,
Unless he take the course that you have done,
Commit me for committing honour, trust it,
La you now, you hear:
When she will take the rein I let her run;
And, I beseech you, hear me, who profess
From your good queen.
Good queen!
Good queen, my lord,
Good queen; I say good queen;
A man, the worst about you.
First hand me: on mine own accord I'll off;
But first I'll do my errand. The good queen,
For she is good, hath brought you forth a daughter;
A mankind witch! Hence with her, out o' door:
A most intelligencing bawd!
Will you not push her out? Give her the bastard.
Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired, unroosted

Take't up, I say; give't to thy crone.
Unvenerable be thy hands, if thou
Takest up the princess by that forced baseness
He dreads his wife.
You'ld call your children yours.
I am none, by this good light.

And now baits me! This brat is none of mine;

And copy of the father, eye, nose, lip,

That cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourself

A most unworthy and unnatural lord
Not she which burns in't. I'll not call you tyrant;
But this most cruel usage of your queen,
Where were her life? she durst not call me so,
I pray you, do not push me; I'll be gone.
Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours:
A better guiding spirit! What needs these hands?
Will never do him good, not one of you.
So, so: farewell; we are gone.
Thou, traitor, hast set on thy wife to this.
A heart so tender o'er it, take it hence
Even thou and none but thou. Take it up straight:
Within this hour bring me word 'tis done,
And by good testimony, or I'll seize thy life,
With what thou else call'st thine. If thou refuse
The bastard brains with these my proper hands
Shall I dash out. Go, take it to the fire;
For thou set'st on thy wife.

I will, my lord.
Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife,

This female bastard hence and that thou bear it

Where chance may nurse or end it. Take it up.

Great Apollo
Turn all to the best! These proclamations,
Will clear or end the business: when the oracle,
Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up,
This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce,
Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried
The daughter of a king, our wife, and one
Of us too much beloved. Let us be clear'd
Produce the prisoner.
It is his highness' pleasure that the queen
Appear in person here in court. Silence!
Leontes, king of Sicilia, thou art here accused and
arraigned of high treason, in committing adultery
with Polixenes, king of Bohemia, and conspiring
with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign
lord the king, thy royal husband: the pretence
of a true subject, didst counsel and aid them, for
their better safety, to fly away by night.
To say 'not guilty:' mine integrity
Behold our human actions, as they do,
Tremble at patience. You, my lord, best know,
Who least will seem to do so, my past life
Hath been as continent, as chaste, as true,
And play'd to take spectators. For behold me
A moiety of the throne a great king's daughter,
The mother to a hopeful prince, here standing
To prate and talk for life and honour 'fore
Who please to come and hear. For life, I prize it
As I weigh grief, which I would spare: for honour,
'Tis a derivative from me to mine,
The bound of honour, or in act or will
That way inclining, harden'd be the hearts
Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin
I ne'er heard yet
That any of these bolder vices wanted
That's true enough;
I loved him as in honour he required,
With such a kind of love as might become
A lady like me, with a love even such,
So and no other, as yourself commanded:
To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke,
Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely
Is that Camillo was an honest man;
You speak a language that I understand not:
My life stands in the level of your dreams,
No father owning it,--which is, indeed,
Look for no less than death.
To me can life be no commodity:
The crown and comfort of my life, your favour,
I do give lost; for I do feel it gone,
Tell me what blessings I have here alive,
That I should fear to die? Therefore proceed.
But yet hear this: mistake me not; no life,

Is altogether just: therefore bring forth,
The Emperor of Russia was my father:
O that he were alive, and here beholding
His daughter's trial! that he did but see
The seal'd-up oracle, by the hand deliver'd
Of great Apollo's priest; and that, since then,
Polixenes blameless; Camillo a true subject; Leontes
and the king shall live without an heir, if that
Now blessed be the great Apollo!
Ay, my lord; even so
My lord the king, the king!

How! gone!
This news is mortal to the queen: look down

Take her hence:

But that the good mind of Camillo tardied

Which you knew great, and to the hazard

O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it,
What fit is this, good lady?
In leads or oils? what old or newer torture
Together working with thy jealousies,
Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle
Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it.
That thou betray'dst Polixenes,'twas nothing;
Thou wouldst have poison'd good Camillo's honour,
To have him kill a king: poor trespasses,
The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter
To be or none or little; though a devil
Nor is't directly laid to thee, the death
Of the young prince, whose honourable thoughts,
Thoughts high for one so tender, cleft the heart
Laid to thy answer: but the last,--O lords,
When I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen,
The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead,
Prevail not, go and see: if you can bring
Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee
To nothing but despair. A thousand knees
Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved
Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault
I' the boldness of your speech.
The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd
To the noble heart. What's gone and what's past help
At my petition; I beseech you, rather
Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman:
The love I bore your queen--lo, fool again!--
I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children;
I'll not remember you of my own lord,
Who is lost too: take your patience to you,
And I'll say nothing.
Thou didst speak but well
When most the truth; which I receive much better
Than to be pitied of thee. Prithee, bring me

I am glad at heart

Come, poor babe:
I have heard, but not believed,
So like a waking. To me comes a creature,
Sometimes her head on one side, some another;
I never saw a vessel of like sorrow,
Since fate, against thy better disposition,
Hath made thy person for the thrower-out
Of my poor babe, according to thine oath,
Places remote enough are in Bohemia,
There weep and leave it crying; and, for the babe
I prithee, call't. For this ungentle business
Put on thee by my lord, thou ne'er shalt see
Thy wife Paulina more.' And so, with shrieks
I did in time collect myself and thought
Hermione hath suffer'd death, and that
Of King Polixenes, it should here be laid,
Either for life or death, upon the earth
Of its right father. Blossom, speed thee well!
Which may, if fortune please, both breed thee, pretty,
And still rest thine. The storm begins; poor wretch,
But my heart bleeds; and most accursed am I

We honour you with trouble: but we came
